titles.title: Campaign Expenditure Limitation Act of 1987
A bill to amend the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to provide for limitations on expenditures in elections for the office of Representative.

action.text: Referred to House Committee on House Administration.
Hearings Held by Subcommittee on Elections Prior to Referral (May 21, 87).

bill.summary: 5/19/1987--Introduced. Campaign Expenditure Limitation Act of 1987 - Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to establish limitations on expenditures in elections for the House of Representatives. Prohibits a candidate from making expenditures from personal funds or immediate family funds which, in the aggregate, exceed $25,000. Prohibits a candidate from making expenditures which, in the aggregate, exceed $200,000. Prohibits any person from making independent expenditures which, in the aggregate, exceed $2,500. Prohibits a candidate from accepting contributions from nonparty multicandidate political committees or from separate segregated funds which, in the aggregate, exceed $50,000. Makes it the duty of the court of appeals and the Supreme Court to expedite judicial review of the constitutionality of any provision of this Act.
